title: Winter salads: how to grow fresh food on a windowsill or balcony
text:
The theory was that come autumn, the Sainsbury’s bag would be emptied and folded away. However, there is little more cheering in the dark, murky days of winter than eating a few cold, rain-washed leaves, fresh from the soil. So the tomatoes are out, and winter greens are in.

When it comes to sowing, I veer more towards the creative, rather than scientific, approach. I've learned the hard way from trying to fit most of a packet of seeds into a couple of (small) containers, but still prefer to take the "one for the air, one for the birds, one for the soil" approach and sow generously in grooves made in the soil straight into the containers.

On my sheltered London balcony the soil is still warm enough at this time of year to encourage germination, as long as it's not let to dry out. But if you have enough windowsill space to sow indoors, and are in chillier climes, then do - just make sure to harden off seedlings when they get more established before shoving them out into the elements.

This winter, I’m growing salad leaves. They’re my favourite edible to grow in the summer, too, for the simple reason that they are what I eat the most of. I have learned the hard way that growing chard is futile - especially so in a small space - because it transpires I don’t have much of an appetite for chard.

Plus, winter leaves are peppery, dark little things that pack a lot of nutrition. They thrive in small spaces, are easy to germinate (I’m still finding errant mustard cropping up in unexpected places two years after I originally sowed some) and are fuss-free. If you’re impatient, you can eat them when they’re small, and they’ll come back again, forgivingly, within a few weeks.
